newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso closes firm as dealers dump dollars.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso closes firm as dealers dump dollars.

text.p: The Mexican peso reversed early weakness to close firm after dealers dumped surplus dollar positions in late trade, dealers said.
"The market had its ups and downs. At first the peso was under pressure, apparently from demand to close end-of-month dollar positions," a trader said.
"Then in late trade dealers stepped in to sell surplus dollars," he added.
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour counterpart closed 0.3 and 0.1 of a centavo firmer, respectively, at 7.5380/7.5410 and 7.5330/7.5380 per dollar.
Several traders agreed that early demand for dollars was actually due more to speculation than to cover end-of-month and -quarter positions.
"I feel that what happened was that a bank tried to put pressure on the dollar by speculating in early trade," a trader said. "Then they were left holding dollars they had to sell."
The same-day peso earlier closed 2.25 centavos weaker at 7.5445/7.5480 per dollar.
Traders said the peso might be weakened on Tuesday if the market expected primary interest rates to rise.
